Situation1: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: An official explains that, because of a registration mismatch, the voter must complete a provisional ballot form before the station closes in ten minutes.
Story: The phone pressed to my ear, I listened as Mr. Jenkins, a long-time customer, raised his voice, demanding to know why our latest offer sounded suspiciously like a scam. My script told me to stay calm, answer every question, and never let a customer feel dismissed. I could hear the frustration in his tone, and I knew I had to handle this carefully—my supervisor was always listening for how we managed objections. But as I tried to explain the offer’s legitimacy, my eyes darted to the clock on the wall. I was at the polling station, squeezed into a corner, headset on, waiting for my turn to vote. An election official called my name, explaining that my registration didn’t match and I’d need to fill out a provisional ballot form—immediately, before the station closed in ten minutes. My heart pounded. I couldn’t hang up on Mr. Jenkins, not without risking my job, but if I didn’t follow the official’s instructions, I’d lose my chance to vote. Torn between the demands of my job and my civic duty, I felt the pressure mounting, my mind racing for a way to satisfy both worlds.
